snippet: Widespread coal use in the north has led in recent decades to an average decrease in life span of more than five years, research indicates.
abstract: Study published in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences finds that Southern Chinese people live on average at least 5 years longer than their northern counterparts in recent decades because of destructive health effects of pollution from widespread use of coal in the north.
lead_paragraph: Widespread coal use in the north has led in recent decades to an average decrease in life span of more than five years, research indicates.

headline.main: Pollution Leads to Drop in Life Span in Northern China, Research Finds
headline.print_headline: Pollution Leads to Drop in Life Span in Northern China, Research Finds

keywords.value: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
